G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides in relevant part that a landlord “shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and that a landlord who does so shall be liable for “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater,” together with costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which protects a tenant against serious interference with the tenancy by the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s control.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly recognizes an implied covenant (warranty) of quiet enjoyment in the tenants’ residential leases and explains that a breach occurs where the landlord’s conduct or permitted conduct seriously interferes with the tenants’ use and enjoyment, including actions by others whom the landlord can control. The court holds that noise from the lounge, operated under a lease the landlords granted and could control, violated the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment and constituted constructive eviction, directly matching the proposition.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). … There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 185C, as this is a civil action involving residential landlord‑tenant rights and arises from conduct occurring in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 185C.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A and G.L. c. 185C, as this is a civil action involving residential landlord‑tenant rights and arises from conduct occurring in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Cambridge Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 218, § 19, because the Premises are located in Cambridge, Middlesex County, and the events giving rise to this action occurred there.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Venue is proper in the Cambridge Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2 and G.L. c. 218, § 19, because the Premises are located in Cambridge, Middlesex County, and the events giving rise to this action occurred there.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been the “landlord” of the Premises within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, and has been responsible for managing, maintaining, and controlling the Premises and adjoining rental units.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached when the landlord, or those acting with the landlord’s permission or under the landlord’s control, create or permit substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, even without an intent to harass the tenant.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that failure to provide heat—which it characterizes as a serious impairment of the premises—constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and it emphasizes that the landlord’s intentions are irrelevant; liability turns on the natural and probable consequences of the landlord’s conduct. Although this case involves the landlord’s own failure to act rather than third parties, its reasoning (focusing on conduct and consequences rather than intent) directly supports the proposition that substantial interference by the landlord or those under their control breaches quiet enjoyment even absent an intent to harass.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’…and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’…liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: A landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 may arise from affirmative acts, from a course of conduct, or from a failure to take reasonable steps to prevent or stop serious interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment occurring on property under the landlord’s control.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” language by importing the common‑law concept, which includes serious interferences caused by a landlord’s acts or omissions, and it upholds liability here based on Gem’s failure to prevent repeated flooding, i.e., an omission. The opinion rejects an intent requirement, explains that liability can rest on the natural and probable consequences of the landlord’s conduct, and emphasizes that Gem is liable because it violated its duty to maintain sanitary conditions and “thereby permitted” flooding on premises under its control. This squarely supports liability arising from affirmative conduct, a course of conduct, or failure to take reasonable steps to stop serious interferences.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744, 747–48 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: A landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 may arise from affirmative acts, from a course of conduct, or from a failure to take reasonable steps to prevent or stop serious interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment occurring on property under the landlord’s control.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant and statutory right of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 only in general, citing prior cases for the standard that it protects against serious interference and usually requires landlord notice and at least negligence. It does not articulate or analyze the more specific proposition that liability may arise from affirmative acts, a course of conduct, or a failure to take reasonable steps to prevent or stop interference; that tripartite formulation comes from other cases, not from this one. Thus, the case does not itself provide authority for the detailed proposition stated.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). Generally, the landlord must have had notice of the condition interfering with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises, and he must have at least acted negligently in not alleviating the condition.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Substantial, continuing noise and disturbance emanating from property or activities controlled by the landlord can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly analyzes the covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that if tenants are unable to use common areas due to serious interference (here, noise, disturbances, threatening crowds and drug activity in landlord‑controlled areas), that can constitute a breach of the covenant. The opinion ties liability to what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done in those areas it owns and controls, making clear that substantial, ongoing disturbance emanating from property or activities the landlord controls may breach quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.proposition: Substantial, continuing noise and disturbance emanating from property or activities controlled by the landlord can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on whether a violation of the lead paint statute, without proof of landlord fault, constitutes a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It discusses required fault levels (at least negligence) and references prior quiet enjoyment cases involving physical defects, but it does not address noise, disturbance, or similar emanations from the landlord’s property or activities. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about substantial, continuing noise and disturbance constituting a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages, including loss of use and enjoyment of the Premises, disruption to work, and diminution in the value of the housing services provided during the affected period, constitute “actual and consequential damages” within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14 only to decide the landlord’s liability standard (negligence vs. recklessness) and to confirm the tenant can recover attorney’s fees under § 14. It does not analyze what categories of harm qualify as “actual and consequential damages” under § 14, nor does it mention loss of use and enjoyment, disruption to work, or diminution in housing services as components of those damages. The cited page therefore does not provide authority for the specific damages proposition stated.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . shall ... be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400 (.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, upon proof of interference with quiet enjoyment, a tenant is entitled to recover either (a) actual and consequential damages or (b) three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400 (.support_reasoning: The court expressly quotes and applies the remedial language of G.L. c. 186, § 14, stating that the statute allows tenants to recover “actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater.” It also recognizes that this recovery is in addition to costs and (by implication under the statute) reasonable attorney’s fees, though the fee issue was not reached on appeal. Thus, the opinion directly supports the proposition about the measure of recovery under § 14 upon proof of interference with quiet enjoyment.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 400 (.relevant_excerpt: “The judge awarded $990 (three months’ rent) to the tenants on a finding that the landlord had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14, the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. General Laws c. 186, § 14, as amended by St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, allows tenants to recover ‘actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater,’ for violation of that statute.”
